addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

20 Febr
u
:
1589
From M
r
Bodley.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H to receave suche further returns
of Answears and Replies, as have passed betweene
me and
e
states,
since I sent yo
w
my last by
S
r
Edward
Norreis
. I send yo
r
H withall a declaration made
by
M
r
Gilpin
and me to
e last Instructions of
e states
G
nr
al, whiche I have exhibited, by vertue of my In-
structions, in her
Ma
ties
name, hoping it will stand with
yo
r
H. good liking. For we finde uppon c
o
ference,
that if
M
r
Beale
had perused my
L. Willughbies
observations, and
e states Answears, he would have
thought himself satisfied, in
e most of his exceptions:
as many of those sette downe by my L. are very
effectuall, and unansweared by
e states. Never-
theles to proceede againe by way of Replie, or to pro-
pose other Articles, would prove an endles debate.
In w
ch
respect we have entred into considerac
o
n
of
e most substantiall pointes, and reduced them
to that forme, w
ch
I send yo
r
H. Whiche had bin
done before nowe, but
at we thought to attend a
fitte opportunitie, when
e rest of
e Councell should
present their griefes aswell as we: wherin they
are busied at this present. It was a part
of my charge from her Ma
tie
to move
e states
G
e
neral for some allowance to my L. Willughby
for
e entertening of intelligences, w
ch
by his owne
advise, and
M
r
Killigrewes,
I was persuaded to
differre: for that we sawe them alienated from him,
exceedingly, continuing so still untill his departure,
Willoughby
nether writing by him to her Ma
tie
nor using any
courteous complement, to testifie their liking of his ser-
vice. Before his departure,
M
r
Allen
was jointly
sent from his L. and me w
t
letters to
e Grave de
Meurs
, and to
e Burghmasters of
Utrecht
, about
e
deliverie of
Deventer
and
Clarehaghen.
I doe expect
his returne every houre. My letter to my
L.
Treasurer
I have left unsealed, req
e
sting yo
r
H. to
reade it: and if
at course w
ch
I propose about
Barne-
velt
, shall by yo
r
H. be thought requisite, I beseche yo
w
fol.56v
that it may be sealed, and delivered. The bearer
herof
Robert Mascal
I sent w
t
her Ma
ties
letter to
S
r
Martin Schincke
, who returned Answear, w
ch
I send yo
r
H. and hath sent for a token to her Ma
tie
e Coullo
rs
of
an Italian capteine, whose c
o
pany he defeated while
this messenger was w
t
him. He requesteth also in
his letter to me, that I would dispatche
e self same
party w
t
his letters into England. I have borne his
charges too and fro in his jorney to Schincke: but for
this voiage into
England,
he is content to relie uppon
suche reward, as yo
r
H. shalbe pleased to procure him,
in respect of bringing
e packet. I hope yo
w
will excuse me to my
Lady,
in
at I am but half as
good as my promise. For I have sent to
Amsterdame,
and all about for gammons of bacon, and can not
gett any till Marche, at w
ch
time they come thither
from
Westphalia.
But I have sent some Edams
cheese, whiche are accounted heere
e best: but if
they prove not so, I can quickly send others.
And so
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage. 20 Fe
b
88
Yo
r
H. most humble to c
o
maund Tho. Bodley.
M
r
Allen is newly returned
from Utrecht, and goeth after
Willoughby
my L. for England, of whome
yo
r
H. may learne uppon
what termes
e Grave
Neuwenar
doth stand, and
e Burgmaisters,
for
e deliverance of Deventer and
Clarehaghen. It seemeth by his report
that an effectuall letter from her Ma
tie
will accomplishe all, though for mine
owne part, I see them all this
contrey over possessed w
t
suche
a carelesnes of gratifieng her
Hig
nes
as I dout
e successe. M
r
Allens
going in this voiage, and other services
heeretofore, in w
ch
my L. hath imploied
him, hath bin somwhat chargeable to his
purse, for w
ch
if yo
r
H. will vouchsafe
to gett him some consideration, he wilbe
e
readier heereafter to bestowe his travell in
e like.
Of S
r
Martin Schinckes forces, and maner of life, he can informe yo
w
at full
fol.57r
This morning a letter from
Ortel
was read in Councell,
wherein he signified, that yo
r
H. complained greatly
of
e biting and presumptuous answear, whiche the
states gave up to my first declaration in her Ma
ties
name: w
ch
e Councell disliked exceedingly, when I
signified
e pointes, whiche I never
did
but privatly before,
for eschewing debate. Howbeit they are not yet ac-
quainted w
t
their later Answears, w
ch
I send heere
w
t
to yo
r
H. being more undiscreete and unseemely, then
e other, and
e very humo
r
of
e writer, who as some
of
e Councell have told me, taketh a direct course in all
maters to ruine himself and
e state. Assoone as this
messenger is departed w
t
them, I will exhibit my Replie
unto them, and geve a copie of
e whole to
e Councell,
for
w
ch
I assure my self, they will utterly condemne
e states, in
sundrie respectes, but most of all in alleaging, that it
doth no more become her Ma
ties
lieutenant and Counsello
rs
,
serving this contrey for their assistance, and upp
o
e charge
of
e contrey, to reason against
e states heere, upp
o
those
Instructions, w
ch
they deliver to
e Councell, then it doth
become Counsello
rs
in other kingdomes to reason against
e Instructions of their Kinges and Souveraignes: w
ch
I
knowe
e Councell of state will take for suche a peevishe
conceat, as
at and other like unadvised clauses, will
turne very muche to
e autors discredit: of w
ch
notw
t
-
standing in any c
o
ference betweene him and me, I doe
not seeme to take notice, as proceeding from him. I did
thinke at my first c
o
ming,
at some familiar insinuation
and seeking unto him w
t
courteous usage might have made
him more tractable: but I finde by experience
at it doth
make him more humorous, and forgetfull what cariage
doth become him. Whiche I thought good uppon
e incident
occasion of Ortels writing, to declare unto yo
r
H.
I shall request yo
r
H. to cause
e booke, w
ch
I send yo
r
H. heerew
t
, to be delivered to my L
Treasuro
r
./.
